items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  8.02
			 
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Use of Board Discretionary, Measure I Bond Funds for Educare Facility
			 
			 
			 
On November 6, 2012, the District voters passed Measure I authorizing the issuance of up to $120,000,000 in Proposition 39 general obligation bonds.  Administration is proposing that up to $1,000,000 in Board discretionary funds from Measure I be used towards the leasing of land from Franklin-McKinley School District for the construction of a portion of the Educare Silicon Valley (“ECSV”) facility thereon.
			 
The proposed ECSV facility would not be located on District property.  It is proposed to be constructed and located on property owned by the Franklin McKinley School District (“FMSD”), but which lies within the jurisdiction of this District.
			 
The Measure I ballot measure provided that expenditures from the bond would be in compliance with the requirements of Article XIIIA, Section 1(b)(3), which provides, in part, that bond funds be used for “for the construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, or replacement of school facilities, including the furnishing and equipping of school facilities, or the acquisition or lease of real property for school facilities . . . .”
			 
The Measure I ballot measure language provided that:
			 
“To upgrade computer/science labs; improve security/safety; repair, equip, and construct classrooms/facilities at Andrew Hill, Calero, Evergreen Valley, Foothill, Independence, James Lick, Mt. Pleasant, Oak Grove, Piedmont Hills, Santa Teresa, Silver Creek, Yerba Buena, Overfelt, and District adult, and alternative, and charter schools; and acquire property for new schools, shall East Side Union High School District issue $120,000,000 of bonds with interest rates below legal limits and no funds for administrator salaries or taken by the State?  (Emphasis added)
			 
The Measure I ballot measure further included that “Bond proceeds may also be expended to acquire real property (or any interest in real property) for future educational and support facilities”.  The Bond Project List which was also a part of the ballot measure specifies that “Bond proceeds will be expended to modernize, replace, renovate, construct, acquire, equip, furnish and otherwise improve the facilities of the District located at the following locations:  . . . ESUHSD Child Care Centers.”  (Emphasis added.)
			 
Administration proposes to use the Measure I funds (not to exceed $1,000,000) to ground lease for a fixed term a portion of the FMSD site for the construction of a portion of the ECSV facility which would house all or a portion of the Early Learning Career Academy and which would serve current and future District students.  The ground lease term would approximate the estimated useable life of the facility so constructed.  A ground lease is an interest in real property.  Pursuant to the Measure I ballot language, bond proceeds may be used to acquire any interest in real property and to construct educational and support facilities for the District’s programs, including but not limited to the District’s Child Care Centers.  
			 
In connection with such a ground lease the District would enter into a construction agreement with ECSV for the Early Learning Career Academy facility portion and a separate joint use and/or operating agreement governing the use and operation of the facility (including, e.g., insurance issues, liability, etc.).
			 
Based on the above, Legal Counsel is of the opinion that the use of Measure I funds for this purpose as proposed within this transactional framework is consistent with Measure I and Proposition 39.
			 
If the Board approves Administration’s recommendations to proceed with negotiations then agreements once memorialized in writing will be presented to the Board for final approval at a future Board meeting.
			 
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Measure I
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not to exceed $1,000,000
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration and Legal Counsel to proceed with negotiations for a ground lease transaction at the planned ECSV site for the construction of a portion of the proposed ECSV facility on Franklin-McKinley School District property, and related agreements.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.04
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:  
					 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Rogelio M. Ruiz, Esq., Legal Counsel
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Final Proposition 39 Facilities Offer and Form of Facilities Use Agreement with KIPP Bay Area Schools Charter
	 
	 
On November 1, 2012, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2013-2014 school year from KIPP Bay Area Schools Charter School.  (“KIPP”).  KIPP has operated a charter high school at the Independence High School campus since 2009/10.  KIPP currently occupies 25 modular classroom units at the IHS site serving approximately 409 students.  Since receiving KIPP’s request, the District has met and conferred with KIPP regarding its facilities needs.  
	 
KIPP desires to remain at the Independence site on a continued multi-year basis.  The Administration requests authority to submit to KIPP a final facilities offer for facilities at the independence site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form (included herewith) subject to subsequent ratification by the Board, for up 26 portable classroom buildings and 2 portable bathroom buildings for KIPP’s charter high school at the Independence site for a term of up to four years (through June 30, 2017).
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measures G, E and/or I
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate with and submit to KIPP a final facilities offer for facilities at the  High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form  (included herewith)  subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  8.05
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:  
						 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, Tom Ryan, KSJC Principal, and Tracy Hanna, Director of Growth, KIPP
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion of KIPP San Jose Collegiate Measure E Bond Request
		 
		 
Under Proposition 39, KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School is eligible for the District’s Bond Measure E proceeds.  Bond funds may only be used to improve District buildings and properties and/or to provide appropriate equipment.  On February 19, 2009, the Board of Trustees approved a Measure E Prioritization List that allocated up to $215,067 to KIPP.
		 
In order to prepare our students for success in college and beyond, KSJC seeks to leverage instructional technology and content solutions to shift the "heavy lifting" of teaching and learning from the teacher to the student, and provide students with opportunities to develop content mastery with a constant feedback loop to monitor their progress.  Instructional technology will also enable teachers to better meet the individual needs of students in an efficient, sustainable manner.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
Presentation Only

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
J. Manuel Herrera, Board Vice President, and Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding School Supplies
	 
	 
At the Board Study Session held on Saturday, March 2, 2013, staff provided information to the Board regarding allocation of Site General Funds as well as categorical funds for school supplies.  At the time of the presentation, sites in general allocated approximately 15-20% of general funds toward instructional supplies.  Furthermore, at the time of the study session, most departments had not spent down approximately 50% of their department allocation.
	 
Due to conflicting anecdotal testimony, the Board requested further information from staff regarding how much, how often and the type of purchases made from out-of-pocket expenses from teachers. 
	 
Staff has completed an on-line survey in order to answer the three questions listed above.  Staff will share results of the survey, as well as provide recommendations for moving forward.
	 
Administration will seek direction from the Board on this item.  At this time, no action is recommended on this item.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-28 In Support of Retaining Adult Education in K-12
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Resolution No. 2012/2013-28
In Support of Retaining Adult Education in K-12
	 
WHEREAS, the first recorded adult education class in California was held in San Francisco in 1856 as authorized by the San Francisco Board of Education to teach English to Irish, Italian, and Chinese immigrants. John Swett, who was the first volunteer teacher for the class, later became a State Superintendent of Public Instruction; and
	 
WHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District began an Adult Education Program in 1988 and is fully accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges; and
	 
WHEREAS, adult schools have been called upon on numerous occasions to assist the state as it dealt with significant social, political, and economic issues. Examples include: job training programs during the Great Depression; training skilled and under skilled workers during World War II; and preparing millions of residents for citizenship; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Adult Education in partnership with Santa Clara County, the City of San Jose, Grail Family Services, Center for Training and Careers and Franklin McKinley School District strengthens communities by providing educational resources to East Side neighborhoods; and
WHEREAS, the East Side Adult Education Program is recognized by the California Department of Educational as providing Programs of Excellence in English as a Second Language , Adult Vocational Education and Adult Basic Education; and
	 
WHEREAS, adult education in California faces its biggest challenge because of the severe economic crisis facing both the state and the nation. Funding that was previously reserved for adult education has been redistributed to other levels of education in the state which has resulted in many adult schools decreasing in size and the actual closing of some schools; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Adult School served over 10,000 students in the 2011-12 school year in two district built adult education facilities and eight neighborhood locations; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Adult School provides significant and varied classes and programs to serve over 10,000 students per year including beginning and advanced technology classes, job preparation classes, high school diploma and GED programs, credit recovery, English as a Second Language (ESL) classes, adult basic education and literacy classes, parent education classes, citizenship classes, healthcare training.; and
	 
WHEREAS, In 2011-12 and 2012/13, East Side Adult School served 2,152 students in the High School Diploma and GED programs.  These programs helped students who were unable to earn their high school diploma during prior to the age of 18.  In the 2011-12 school year 148 students earned their high school diploma, 79 students earned their GED; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Adult School served 465 students in the Adult Basic Education program in the 2011-12 school year.  This program builds basic educational skills in reading, writing and mathematics for student transition to a high school diploma or GED program; and 
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Adult School serves over 600 high school students per year in credit recovery who, because of this program are able to graduate with their class or stay on track for graduation; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Adult School served 6,085 students in the English as a Second Language (ESL) Program in the 2011-12 school year and parents enrolled in ESL classes learn how to assist their children with school work and dedicate several hours a year tutoring their own children; and 
	 
WHEREAS, K-12 Adult Education is focused on the State’s economic recovery by providing the education to foster employability of low-skilled workers as evidenced by our East Side Adult School training of 610 CTE students in 2011-12, of which 265 were economically disadvantaged; and
	 
WHEREAS, the Board of Trustees of the East Side Union High School District strongly supports retaining Adult Education as an important part of the East Side Union High School District.
	 
BE IT THEREFORE RESOLVED that the Board of Trustees of the East Side Union School District strongly urges the Governor of California, Jerry Brown, and the California Department of Education and the State Legislature to retain Adult Education programs in the current configuration with oversight by K-12 grade or high school districts in California and to increase state funding for Adult Education at the proposed level for Community Colleges.
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 16th day of April, 2013, by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.

Item:  11.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-29 in Support of Senate Constitutional Amendment 3 (SCA 3) Authored by Senators Mark Leno, Jerry Hill and Fran Pavley
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Resolution to Support
Senate Constitutional Amendment 3 (SCA 3)
Authored by Senators Mark Leno, Jerry Hill and Fran Pavley
Resolution No. 2012/2013-29
	 
WHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District Governing Board is committed to making policy and financial decisions that enable the school district/county office of education to provide quality educational programs and services to the school-age children of our community; and 
	 
WHEREAS, since the onset of the state’s fiscal crisis in 2008, public schools statewide have experienced unprecedented funding reductions and apportionment deferrals totaling more than $20 billion; and 
	 
WHEREAS, the passage of Proposition 30, Schools and Local Public Safety Protection Act, in November 2012, by an overwhelming majority of the state’s voters will help stave off excessive cuts and deferrals to schools; and 
	 
WHEREAS, California public schools remain underfunded and continue to rank 47th out of the 50 states in per-pupil spending with the state investing $2,850 less per pupil and roughly $70,000 less per classroom than the national average; and 
WHEREAS, our schools and communities need additional tools at the local level to provide funding and support programs; and 
	 
WHEREAS, the current threshold needed to pass a local parcel tax impedes the ability of local communities to raise revenue, even if approved by a significant majority of local voters; and 
	 
WHEREAS, Senators Mark Leno, Jerry Hill and Fran Pavley have introduced SCA 3 to require that local parcel taxes receive a 55 percent vote on a local ballot in order to pass; and 
	 
WHEREAS, SCA 3 contains accountability elements, including the requirement of approval of the proposition by a majority of the members of the local governing board, an annual independent audit, and a citizens’ oversight committee, and allows an exemption from the parcel tax for parcels owned by persons over the age of 65 or those receiving Supplement Security Income for a disability (SSI); and 
	 
WHEREAS, the California School Boards Association (CSBA), representing nearly 1,000 school district governing boards and regional educational agencies, is a co-sponsor and supports the passage of SCA 3 and its placement on the ballot for approval by voters statewide, 
	 
THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that the East Side Union High School District Governing Board joins CSBA and school districts and county offices of education around the State in supporting passage of this measure by the Legislature and placement on a statewide ballot for voter approval, 
	 
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that this body, the East Side Union High School District, supports the passage of SCA 3 because it provides local communities an additional tool to secure funding to sustain and restore educational programs and enable districts to buy needed curriculum materials, classroom technology and restore teaching and student support positions. 
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 16th day of April, 2013, by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Coordinated Early Intervening Services (CEIS) Plan
	 
In the summer of 2012, the East Side Union High School District was identified as having significant disproportionality as noted in the requirements of Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) for 2010-2011.  CDE determined that East Side Union High School District has had a disproportionate number of white students classified as Emotionally Disturbed for the last four years. 
	 
Further analysis using the Alternate Risk Ratio revealed that although the numbers were small in the amount of students over the expected or acceptable threshold based upon enrollment numbers, the trend persisted indicating that significant root causes were underlying these findings.  
	 
In accordance with the federal and state requirements, a planning group was convened to conduct a self-study and to develop a Coordinated Early Intervening Services Plan (CEIS).  The existing DELAC-DAC committee has been identified, and also expanded, to be the leadership team and has reviewed the disproportionality findings and the process needed to respond to this finding.
	 
The CEIS Planning has given the District an opportunity to focus on processes for identification, referral, consideration of Least Restrictive Environment, and placement into Special Education.  East Side partnered with WestEd to conduct extensive review and research in our district.  They gathered much information, and shared their review through four data points: individual interviews with district leadership; IEP file reviews; focus groups with a cross-section of staff and parents; and an online survey made available to every full-time employee in the district..  Their report summarized the efforts that the district had taken to provide both behavioral and academic interventions for student. 
	 
ESUHSD staff chose to work through a hybrid pathway combining Policies and Procedures, the development of a multi-tiered intervention system, and Closing the Achievement Gap through professional development and increased collaboration time.  There is considerable overlap in several of the pathways.  Three components have been identified to assist in addressing the root causes of the disproportionality:
	 
Incorporation of consistent Policies and Procedures that promote equitable access to the LRE
Incorporation of a multi-tiered intervention Model including Positive Behavior Support Systems and Academic Interventions
Increased Time for Collaboration among Regular Staff, and professional development to address meeting the needs of all learners and Closing the Achievement Gap
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Coordinated Early Intervening Services (CEIS) Plan.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From East Side Union High School District to California School Employees Association, Chapter 187
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the California School Employees Association for the 2013-2014 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its classified employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 2013-2014 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; contract language amendments to Articles 14, 15, 16, 17, 20, 21, Appendix E and Appendix H-1.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board adopt the District’s initial proposal to the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187.

Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator, and Randy Phelps, Director of Information Technology
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action on the Plan for District Wide Copiers
	 
	 
This presentation is a follow-up from the January 17, 2013 Board presentation of the Request for Proposals (RFP) of Copier Equipment and Services.
	 
Since that time Administration has conducted a more extensive evaluation of the District’s collection of leased and purchased machines.  The review looked at their age, serviceability, features, technology, and other relevant information to help us determine a recommendation that would give the District the best equipment to move forward with in the future that will bring the technology to meet the needs of the teachers, staff, and students.
	 
It is our recommendation that Administration re-issues an RFP to replace much of the Districts old owned copiers with new leased copiers for a period of 3, 4, or 5 years (depending on the best value proposal). By doing a single RFP will give the District the ability to procure using volume.  The District will also be able to replace copiers every 3-5 years with new equipment helping us to stay current with technology.  Another benefit is that vendors will be obligated to replace “bad” or “lemon” copiers with new copiers.
  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Estimated Increase $40,000 annually 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Site General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve administration to re-issues an RFP to replace much of the District's old owned copiers with new leased copiers, and maintenance agreements and to acquire the best value proposal to stay current with technology.

Item:  14.03
		 
Amended
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:  
						 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Delegate Authority to the Superintendent or Designee to Dispose of Surplus/Obsolete Equipment/Furniture Items per Education Code Sections 17545 and 17546  
		 
		 
Administration works closely with all departments and each School Site to expeditiously remove old furniture and equipment that is no longer being used by the District. Administration is seeking Delegation of Authority to dispose of low valued items under $2,500 (i.e. desk, chairs, tables, printers, etc.) on an as needed basis.  Administration will provide the Board with a list and resolution of the items on a quarterly basis for ratification.
		 
Historically, Administration takes lists of old furniture and/or equipment that are no longer of used by the District to the Board monthly or on an as needed basis. Once the list of items is approved, Administration then moves the items to a central location and begins the surplus removal process (donation, sale, or disposal). This process can take up to three months depending on when the board meeting is and when the list is submitted to purchasing.
		 
Due to very tight timelines with regards to our modernization projects and working with our school sites and construction managers these items must be moved very quickly.  Administration would be able to utilize contractors and other resources to have items marked for surplus taken care of while still at the site versus having the items moved two and three times.  We are also working out a system to have non-profit organizations come and pick up items directly from sites also so as to reduce the number of time items have to be moved. 
		 
By granting this delegation, it will allow Administration to quickly respond to the sites need to have old, unused furniture and/or equipment removed and disposed of in a quick efficient manner.  
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve authorization for the Superintendent and/or designee to dispose of surplus furniture and equipment as needed and to provide the Board of Trustees with a list and resolution of the items on a quarterly basis for ratification. The term of this delegation is April 17, 2013 through August 31, 2015.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  16.04
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of California Interscholastic Federation (CIF) Application for Renewal of 2013-2014 Multi-School Membership
	 
	 
Pursuant to California Interscholastic Federation regulations, CIF-member schools may allow only students currently enrolled, in grades 9-12, in their school, to participate in any CIF competition.  Any CIF-member school that wishes to allow participation on its team(s) by students, who are currently enrolled in non-CIF-member schools or programs which do not offer any interscholastic athletic programs (i.e. small but necessary schools), may request approval to do so.
	 
The administrative responsibility for all students involved in athletics shall rest with the Principal of the CIF-member school for which the student(s) is competing.  Students must meet all the CIF-member scholastic eligibility requirements.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$14,557.41
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the California Interscholastic Federation Application for Renewal of 2013-2014 Multi-School Membership.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  16.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
	 
				A
				B
				C
				D
				E
				F

				H
				I

				P

				U

				X

				Z
